Blurb
Overview
This module will develop students’ knowledge, skills, and methods for investigating and controlling human and animal disease outbreaks. It will provide students with an opportunity to deal with the different phases of an outbreak from start to finish. It will build on the knowledge and skills they have developed over the course of their studies and allow them to apply this to control of disease outbreaks. The importance of developing knowledge and skills in this area is evidenced by the Covid-19 pandemic. The module comprises lectures, seminars, and workshops led by academics with expertise in the investigation of, and control of outbreaks. Students will also engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool.

Students will be given three summative assessments over the course of the module.
1. A piece of science communication writing such as a POSTnote or policy document
2. A group poster presentation on a disease outbreak with an individual pitch
Educational Aims
The module aims to:

Develop student understanding of the methodologies used for the investigation, surveillance and control of human and animal disease outbreaks.

Support the development of transferable skills in critical thinking, interpretation of data and science communication in the context of disease outbreaks.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is a 15 credit third year module that allows students to develop knowledge, skills, and techniques for investigating and controlling human and animal disease outbreaks. It will build on the knowledge and skills they have developed over the course of their studies and allow them to apply this to control of disease outbreaks. The importance of developing knowledge and skills in this area is evidenced by the Covid-19 pandemic. The module comprises lectures, seminars, and workshops led by academics with expertise in the investigation of, and control of outbreaks.

The module will be assessed by a piece of written science communication and a group poster presentation on a disease outbreak with an individual pitch.
Outline Syllabus
The module begins with an introduction to the simulated disease outbreak. Students will be provided with an outbreak scenario and will be expected to investigate and design control strategies to bring the outbreak under control. To support this, students will have lectures covering the different phases of the investigation and control of a global human and animal outbreak.

This will include topics such as the following:
1. Examples of different human and animal disease outbreaks
2. Identifying a disease outbreak event
3. The outbreak response and the implementation of different control interventions and strategies
4. The roles and responsibilities of different organisations and stakeholders during an outbreak
5. Communication during an outbreak including writing for different audiences and engaging with the media.
6. Understanding the Epidemiology and looking at risk factors and control interventions
7. The role of surveillance
8. The cost and impact of control interventions and strategies

Students will develop team working skills whilst undertaking the disease outbreak scenario and will be guided in the investigation and control of the outbreak by an academic supervisor. Emphasis will be placed on critically evaluating data from a variety of sources.

Student learning will be enhanced through engagement with departmental research seminars that cover a broad range of current research topics. This will enable the students to appreciate the diversity of Microbiology and Infection research and how it can be applied to disease outbreaks. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, acquiring up-to-date information straight from a vibrant research community.

Workshops will include sessions that focus on human or animal outbreaks, interventions, epidemiological studies, surveillance systems, bioinformatics and economics of selected diseases. Students will also undertake workshops in summarising scientific papers and undertake group work to investigate and control a simulated disease outbreak.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Students will work in small groups to investigate and control a simulated disease outbreak. Students will present their posters in an authentic conference-style session at the end of the module. The module will utilise lectures, workshops and seminars. An average week would include 1 x 50 minute lecture and 1 x 50 minute workshop and/or seminar.

Teaching method 1 – Lectures
Research-connected lectures will introduce key subject matter, drawing upon high-profile real-world examples related to the theme/ topic areas outlined in the Outline Syllabus section.
Attendence recorded: Yes

Teaching method 2 – Seminars
Research seminars or guest lectures by experts in their fields, linked to the themed topic areas will direct student learning, allow interactive discussions, and will enable incorporation of current research.
Attendence recorded: Yes

Teaching method 3 – Workshops
The workshop tasks, linked to themed topic areas, will require students to work individually as well as in small groups, to develop, discuss and/or debate topics. The workshops will foster critical thinking and provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore greater breadth of issues and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives.

Attendence recorded: Yes
Teaching method 4 – Self-directed learning
Self-directed learning will include reading research papers and additional content provided alongside lectures, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module; student time will also be spent developing materials and skills prior to assessments.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment.

The module will be assessed via two assessments

Assessment 1: A group poster and individual pitch
A group poster of control measures and intervention strategies used for a human or animal global outbreak. The assessment is designed to aid skills to visually communicate key aspects that may help to prevent and mitigate infection among at-risk populations. Student's work will be assessed in an authentic conference-style session at the end of the module. Students will also be required to deliver an individual short verbal pitch about an aspect of their poster and discuss their contribution to the group poster . The group poster will contribute 50% of the marks for this assessment and the other 50% will come from the individual pitch

Assessment 2: Written Science Communication
Students will produce a written science communication. This could be a POSTnote which is written for a non-specialist audience (Members of Parliament) or a policy document.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

The workshops will foster critical thinking and provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore greater breadth of issues and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives.

Attendence recorded: Yes
Teaching method 4 – Self-directed learning
Self-directed learning will include reading research papers and additional content provided alongside lectures, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module; student time will also be spent developing materials and skills prior to assessments.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment.

The module will be assessed via two assessments

Assessment 1: A group poster and individual pitch
A group poster of control measures and intervention strategies used for a human or animal global outbreak. The assessment is designed to aid skills to visually communicate key aspects that may help to prevent and mitigate infection among at-risk populations. Student's work will be assessed in an authentic conference-style session at the end of the module. Students will also be required to deliver an individual short verbal pitch about an aspect of their poster and discuss their contribution to the group poster . The group poster will contribute 50% of the marks for this assessment and the other 50% will come from the individual pitch

Assessment 2: Written Science Communication
Students will produce a written science communication. This could be a POSTnote which is written for a non-specialist audience (Members of Parliament) or a policy document.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Overview
This module will develop students’ knowledge, skills, and methods for investigating and controlling human and animal disease outbreaks. It will provide students with an opportunity to deal with the different phases of an outbreak from start to finish. It will build on the knowledge and skills they have developed over the course of their studies and allow them to apply this to control of disease outbreaks. The importance of developing knowledge and skills in this area is evidenced by the Covid-19 pandemic. The module comprises lectures, seminars, and workshops led by academics with expertise in the investigation of, and control of outbreaks. Students will also engage with research seminar presentations that highlight the direction and strengths of ongoing research at Liverpool.

Students will be given three summative assessments over the course of the module.
1. A piece of science communication writing such as a POSTnote or policy document
2. A group poster presentation on a disease outbreak with an individual pitch
Educational Aims
The module aims to:

Develop student understanding of the methodologies used for the investigation, surveillance and control of human and animal disease outbreaks.

Support the development of transferable skills in critical thinking, interpretation of data and science communication in the context of disease outbreaks.
Marketing Module Synopsis
This is a 15 credit third year module that allows students to develop knowledge, skills, and techniques for investigating and controlling human and animal disease outbreaks. It will build on the knowledge and skills they have developed over the course of their studies and allow them to apply this to control of disease outbreaks. The importance of developing knowledge and skills in this area is evidenced by the Covid-19 pandemic. The module comprises lectures, seminars, and workshops led by academics with expertise in the investigation of, and control of outbreaks.

The module will be assessed by a piece of written science communication and a group poster presentation on a disease outbreak with an individual pitch.
Outline Syllabus
The module begins with an introduction to the simulated disease outbreak. Students will be provided with an outbreak scenario and will be expected to investigate and design control strategies to bring the outbreak under control. To support this, students will have lectures covering the different phases of the investigation and control of a global human and animal outbreak.

This will include topics such as the following:
1. Examples of different human and animal disease outbreaks
2. Identifying a disease outbreak event
3. The outbreak response and the implementation of different control interventions and strategies
4. The roles and responsibilities of different organisations and stakeholders during an outbreak
5. Communication during an outbreak including writing for different audiences and engaging with the media.
6. Understanding the Epidemiology and looking at risk factors and control interventions
7. The role of surveillance
8. The cost and impact of control interventions and strategies

Students will develop team working skills whilst undertaking the disease outbreak scenario and will be guided in the investigation and control of the outbreak by an academic supervisor. Emphasis will be placed on critically evaluating data from a variety of sources.

Student learning will be enhanced through engagement with departmental research seminars that cover a broad range of current research topics. This will enable the students to appreciate the diversity of Microbiology and Infection research and how it can be applied to disease outbreaks. It also affords students the opportunity to engage with active researchers in an authentic way, acquiring up-to-date information straight from a vibrant research community.

Workshops will include sessions that focus on human or animal outbreaks, interventions, epidemiological studies, surveillance systems, bioinformatics and economics of selected diseases. Students will also undertake workshops in summarising scientific papers and undertake group work to investigate and control a simulated disease outbreak.
Teaching and Learning Methods
Students will work in small groups to investigate and control a simulated disease outbreak. Students will present their posters in an authentic conference-style session at the end of the module. The module will utilise lectures, workshops and seminars. An average week would include 1 x 50 minute lecture and 1 x 50 minute workshop and/or seminar.

Teaching method 1 – Lectures
Research-connected lectures will introduce key subject matter, drawing upon high-profile real-world examples related to the theme/ topic areas outlined in the Outline Syllabus section.
Attendence recorded: Yes

Teaching method 2 – Seminars
Research seminars or guest lectures by experts in their fields, linked to the themed topic areas will direct student learning, allow interactive discussions, and will enable incorporation of current research.
Attendence recorded: Yes

Teaching method 3 – Workshops
The workshop tasks, linked to themed topic areas, will require students to work individually as well as in small groups, to develop, discuss and/or debate topics. The workshops will foster critical thinking and provide a platform for students to synthesise and discuss content in greater depth, explore greater breadth of issues and evaluate scenarios and alternative perspectives.

Attendence recorded: Yes
Teaching method 4 – Self-directed learning
Self-directed learning will include reading research papers and additional content provided alongside lectures, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module; student time will also be spent developing materials and skills prior to assessments.

Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The assessment strategy has been guided by the Liverpool Curriculum Framework attributes and hallmarks, particularly with respect to confidence, active learning, digital fluency, and authentic assessment.

The module will be assessed via two assessments

Assessment 1: A group poster and individual pitch
A group poster of control measures and intervention strategies used for a human or animal global outbreak. The assessment is designed to aid skills to visually communicate key aspects that may help to prevent and mitigate infection among at-risk populations. Student's work will be assessed in an authentic conference-style session at the end of the module. Students will also be required to deliver an individual short verbal pitch about an aspect of their poster and discuss their contribution to the group poster . The group poster will contribute 50% of the marks for this assessment and the other 50% will come from the individual pitch

Assessment 2: Written Science Communication
Students will produce a written science communication. This could be a POSTnote which is written for a non-specialist audience (Members of Parliament) or a policy document.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data will differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
